org.fujion.plotly.plot

Class PlotOHLC

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.fujion.ancillary.Options
      • org.fujion.plotly.plot.PlotOptions
        • org.fujion.plotly.plot.PlotOHLC
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    OptionMap.IOptionMapConverter, IClientTransform

    public class PlotOHLC
extends PlotOptions
    Options for OHLC plot.

    An open-high-low-close chart (also OHLC) is a type of chart typically used to illustrate movements in the price of a financial instrument over time. Each vertical line on the chart shows the price range (the highest and lowest prices) over one unit of time, e.g., one day or one hour. Tick marks project from each side of the line indicating the opening price (e.g., for a daily bar chart this would be the starting price for that day) on the left, and the closing price for that time period on the right. The bars may be shown in different hues depending on whether prices rose or fell in that period.

public String[] text$array
        Hover text elements associated with each sample point. The items are mapped in order to this trace's sample points.

      • text$string

        @Option(value="text")
public String text$string
        Hover text elements associated with each sample point to the same value.

      • tickwidth

        @Option
public Double tickwidth
        The width of the open/close tick marks relative to the "x" minimal interval.

        Constraints: ≥0 and ≤0.5

        Default: 0.3

      • x

        @Option
public double[] x
        The x coordinates. If absent, linear coordinate will be generated.

      • xaxis

        @Option
public String xaxis
        Reference between this trace's x coordinates and a 2D Cartesian x axis. If "x" (the default value), the x coordinates refer to "layout.xaxis". If "x2", the x coordinates refer to "layout.xaxis2", and so on.

      • xcalendar

        @Option
public CalendarTypeEnum xcalendar
        The calendar system to use with "x" date data.

        Default: GREGORIAN

      • yaxis

        @Option
public String yaxis
        Reference between this trace's y coordinates and a 2D Cartesian y axis. If "y" (the default value), the y coordinates refer to "layout.yaxis". If "y2", the y coordinates refer to "layout.xaxis2", and so on.
